I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to the People’s Republic of China (PRC) for the Anhui Chao Lake Environmental Rehabilitation 
Project.1 
 
2.  The project will support the Anhui provincial government (APG) to implement the Master 
Plan for Integrated Water Environmental Management in the Chao Lake Basin (2008–2020).2  
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
A.  Rationale 
3.  Chao Lake is the fifth largest freshwater lake in the PRC. Its catchment covers about 
10% of the total area of Anhui province. The lake is important to industrial and agricultural water 
supply,  water  transport,  tourism,  and  recreation  in  Anhui  province.  Since  1990,  the  water 
environment of Chao Lake has been deteriorating because of the adverse environmental effects 
of rapid economic growth and urban development. During 2000–2009, the urban population in 
the catchment increased by 30% and gross domestic product increased by 500%. 
 
4.  In 1996, Chao Lake was identified as one of the top three priority lakes in the PRC for 
environmental rehabilitation due to its poor water quality. Since then, the provincial and local 
governments concerned, supported by the national government and ADB, have provided large 
investments  to  control  municipal  and  industrial  pollution  in  the  lake  catchment.3 These 
investments have reduced industrial and municipal wastewater to a certain extent, but they have 
not addressed all dimensions of the water quality problems in the lake. Chao Lake continues to 
receive excessive amounts of organic matters, nitrogen, and phosphorous. Particularly during 
summer, elevated levels of pollutants and high temperatures result in algal blooms, depletion of 
oxygen, and the emission of offensive odors. 
 
5.  The present average water quality in the lake is class IV under the PRC’s national 
environmental water quality standard, and 50% of water monitoring points in the lake are still 
class V. This represents a slight improvement over the situation in 2005 when overall water 
quality in the lake was class V+, but is still far from the government’s long-term objective for the 
lake of class III.4 
 
6.  As a result of past investments and regulatory efforts, industrial pollution control in the 
lake catchment has improved. The two main pollution sources yet to be fully controlled are 
                                                
1  Asian Development Bank (ADB). 2010. Technical Assistance to the People’s Republic of China for Preparing the 
Anhui  Chao  Lake  Environmental  Rehabilitation  Project.  Manila  (TA  7701-PRC,  $900,000,  approved  on  10 
December). 
2   The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
3  ADB. 1996. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Loan to the 
People’s Republic of China for Anhui Environmental Improvement Project for Municipal Wastewater Treatment. 
Manila; and ADB. 1996. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Loan to 
the People’s Republic of China for Anhui Environmental Improvement Project for Industrial Pollution Abatement. 
Manila. 
4 Class III water is suitable as a supply source for a municipal drinking water treatment plant and for swimming. 
Class IV water is suitable for use as a general industrial water supply and for recreational use involving no direct 
human contact with the water. Class V water is suitable only for agricultural water supply and general landscaping 
use. Class V+ water is unsuitable for any use (PRC Environmental Water Quality Standard GB3838-2002).

2 
municipal point sources5 and nonpoint source emissions.6 The Anhui Environmental Protection 
Department  estimates  that  municipal  sources  account  for  about  50%  of  existing  organic 
emissions into the lake, 57% of emissions of nitrogen, and 54% of phosphorous. Rural nonpoint 
source emissions are estimated to account for 42% of organic emissions, 38% of nitrogen, and 
42% of phosphorous.7   
 
7.  Strategic  planning  and  institutional  reform.  The  APG  understands  that  a 
comprehensive approach is required to solve water quality problems in Chao Lake. Such an 
approach requires not only continuous investments to control pollution sources but also the 
adoption of a strategic planning framework. To support a comprehensive approach, the APG 
has formulated the Chao Lake Environmental Rehabilitation Master Plan (2008–2020). The 
master plan suggests the need for about CNY50 billion of investments to develop a wide range 
of  structural  and  nonstructural  measures.  These  measures  include  (i)  a  strengthened 
institutional mechanism, (ii) expanded and upgraded municipal wastewater treatment plants 
(WWTPs),  (iii)  extension  of  sewerage  networks,  (iv)  a  continuous  industrial  wastewater 
treatment control program, (v) comprehensive rural nonpoint source pollution control, (vi) control 
of other nonpoint source pollution sources through in-stream measures, (vii) water conservation, 
(viii) strengthened regulatory supervision, (ix) applied research, and (x) public education. 
 
8.  After the master plan was issued, the APG took the following two important steps to 
strengthen institutional arrangements in managing the lake basin environment: (i) reorganizing 
local governments in the lake catchment so that the management responsibilities for the entire 
surface area, the lake foreshores, and most of the upper catchment area were transferred to a 
single  local  government  authority—the  Hefei  municipality;  and  (ii)  creating  the  Chao  Lake 
Management Authority (CLMA), a new subprovincial agency, to provide unified administration of 
general affairs relating to the management of Chao Lake. In August 2011, the State Council 
ordered the establishment of the CLMA to manage all of the lake’s water-related matters, 
including land use planning, water quality and quantity issues, fisheries, navigation, and tourism. 
The CLMA could be the first lake or river management agency in the PRC that has a sufficiently 
comprehensive management purview and the first to deal with all aspects of the water cycle.8 
   
9.  Lessons. Sustainable management of a lake basin is widely recognized as difficult. An 
international study on 28 lakes across the world, financed by the Global Environmental Facility, 
identified  measures  that  would  lead  to  effective  lake  basin  management:  (i)  adequate 
institutions, (ii) right policy framework, (iii) meaningful stakeholder participation, (iv) relevant 
technical strategies, (v) adequate monitoring data, and (vi) adequate financing.9 ADB’s own 
analytical work supports a similar conclusion.10 Although all of these six measures have been 
applied in managing the Chao Lake basin, their implementation has not been comprehensive or 
                                                
5  Municipal point sources are mainly liquid waste emissions from urban areas not yet serviced by sewerage systems, 
and inadequately treated emissions from existing municipal wastewater treatment plants which were not designed 
to remove nutrients. 
6  Nonpoint source emissions are a result of discharges of domestic waste from unsewered rural households, runoff 
from farmers’ fields, waste discharges from animal production enterprises and resuspension of polluted sediments, 
and erosion of river banks during high flow conditions. 
7  Industrial point sources account for less than 8% of organic emissions and 6% of nutrient emissions to the lake. 
8  Q. F. Zhang and M. Bennett. 2011. Eco-compensation for Watershed Services in the People’s Republic of China. 
Manila: ADB. 
9  International Lake Environment Committee Foundation. 2005. Managing Lakes and their Basins for Sustainable 
Use: A Report for Lake Basin Managers and Stakeholders. Japan. 
10 Q. F. Zhang et al. 2008. Reviving Lakes and Wetlands: Lessons Learned from the Peoples’ Republic of China. 
Manila: ADB.

3 
satisfactory. The assessment is detailed in a knowledge product entitled Sustainable Lake 
Management: Implications for Chao Lake Rehabilitation.11  
 
10.  The project supports the PRC’s sustainable development agenda for establishing an 
environmentally friendly, resource-efficient, and harmonious society, as outlined in the PRC’s 
Twelfth Five-Year Plan, 2011–2015. The project will support the master plan and the PRC’s 
Twelfth Five-Year Plan for Chao Lake environmental protection, and introduce an integrated 
approach to overcoming current constraints on restoring the lake environment. The project is 
aligned  with  ADB’s  country  partnership  strategy,  2011–2015  for  the  PRC  in  supporting 
environmental sustainability and inclusive growth.12 
 
B.  Impact and Outcome 
11.  The project impact will be improved quality of life and a sustainable aquatic ecosystem in 
Chao Lake. The outcome will be improved water resources and environment in Chao Lake and 
upstream rivers. 
 
C.  Outputs 
12.  The project comprises four outputs: (i) increased municipal point source pollution control, 
(ii) enhanced nonpoint source pollution control, (iii) improved institutional capacity of the CLMA, 
and (iv) strengthened project management capacity. 
 
13.  Increased  municipal  point  source  pollution  control.  This  output  includes  (i) 
construction of 584 kilometers of wastewater collection network in developed urban areas that 
are currently unsewered, and interception of untreated sewer discharges that currently flow 
directly into the tributaries of Chao Lake; and (ii) design and construction of eight WWTPs in 
areas where collection systems will be constructed under the project.13 All WWTPs constructed 
under the project will be of class 1A design which provides for active nutrient removal.   
 
14.  Enhanced  nonpoint  source  pollution  control.  This  output  includes  (i)  dredging, 
embankment works, vegetated buffer zones, and enhanced habitat for biota and erosion control 
in eight upstream rivers; (ii) implementation of a solid-waste collection and management project 
in Feidong county to control drifting objects in the area; (iii) construction of artificial wetlands and 
enhanced habitats to reduce nutrient loads into the lake; and (iv) support for a pilot rural 
nonpoint source pollution control activity focusing on the control of agricultural pollution sources. 
 
15.  An eco-compensation program that stimulates nutrient recycling between animal wastes 
and crop growing through an incentive-based approach will be implemented. It will subsidize the 
production of organic fertilizer from animal wastes and provide incentives for farmers to replace 
chemical fertilizers with organic fertilizers. In addition, nutrient trading between point sources 
and nonpoint sources in Chao Lake will be tested.  
 
16.  Improved institutional capacity of the Chao Lake Management Authority. This output 
will comprise an institutional development and capacity building program for the CLMA. The 
program will include staff training through domestic and international educational programs, 
procurement of equipment, and a series of studies on (i) spatial land use management of the 
Chao Lake catchment based on water quality functional zoning, (ii) an early warning system for 
                                                
11 Executive  Summary  of  Knowledge  Product:  Sustainable  Lake  Management:  Implications  for  Chao  Lake 
Rehabilitation (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
12 ADB. 2012. Country Partnership Strategy: People’s Republic of China, 2011–2015. Manila.  
13 In these areas, there is currently no WWTP or the existing WWTP is undersized.

4 
algal bloom outbreaks, and (iii) mechanisms to apply and promote the demonstration results in 
controlling nonpoint source pollution. In addition, through a knowledge partnership with the 
United  Nations  Educational,  Scientific,  and  Cultural  Organization-International  Institute  for 
Hydraulic and Environmental Engineering, ADB is engaging its staff to conduct the capacity 
building for the CLMA, which will help develop the understanding and capacity of CLMA staff to 
apply principles of integrated water resources management. 
 
17.  Strengthened project management capacity. This output will provide support through 
an  international  consulting  company  to  assist  the  project  management  offices  (PMOs)  on 
engineering design review, procurement, and project management and supervision. Selected 
PMO staff will receive training at the early stage of the project, including training on financial 
management,  disbursement,  and  procurement  procedures;  safeguard  requirements;  and 
reporting. Consulting services will also be provided to ensure the project’s sustainability through 
(i) corporatizing and strengthening wastewater services in the project areas,14 and (ii) reforming 
wastewater tariffs to ensure sustainable operations and adoption of a pro-poor approach. 
 
D.  Investment and Financing Plans 
18.  The  project  is  estimated  to  cost  $432.11  million,  including  contingencies  of  $49.57 
million, financing charges of $13.99 million, and taxes and duties of $21.50 million. ADB will 
finance taxes and duties on items financed by ADB loan.15 The investment plan is summarized 
in Table 1 and detailed in the project administration manual (PAM).16 
 
Table 1: Project Investment Plan

  4.  Strengthened project management capacity  2.35 
    Subtotal (A)  368.55 
B.  Contingenciesc  49.57

16 Project Administration Manual (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

5 
19.  The government has requested a loan of $250 million, or 57.86% of the total project 
cost, from ADB’s ordinary capital resources to help finance the project. The loan will have a 25-
year term, including a grace period of 5 years, an annual interest rate determined in accordance 
with  ADB's  London  interbank  offered  rate  (LIBOR)-based  lending  facility,17 a  commitment 
charge of 0.15% per year (the interest and other charges during construction to be capitalized in 
the  loan),  and  such  other  terms  and  conditions  set  forth  in  the  draft  loan  and  project 
agreements. The government has provided ADB with (i) the reasons for its decision to borrow 
under ADB’s LIBOR-based lending facility based on these terms and conditions, and (ii) an 
undertaking that these choices were its own independent decision and not made in reliance on 
any communication or advice from ADB. 
 
20.  The financing plan is in Table 2. Government counterpart financing amounts to $182.11 
million,  or  42.14%  of  the  total  project  cost  to  cover  civil  works;  design,  monitoring,  and 
management expenses; taxes and duties; and contingencies. 
 
Table 2: Financing Plan 
Amount  Share of Total 
Source  ($ million)    (%) 
Asian Development Bank  250.00    57.86 
Municipal/county governments  182.11    42.14 
  432.11    100.00 
Source: Asian Development Bank estimates. 
 
21.  The borrower will be the Government of the PRC. The government will make the loan 
proceeds  available  to  the  APG.  The  APG  will  make  the  loan  proceeds  available  to  the 
participating municipal and county governments, which in turn will make the loan proceeds 
available to the implementing agencies. The APG will assume the foreign exchange and interest 
rate variation risks for the loan. The onlending arrangements and indicative funds flow diagram 
are provided in the PAM (footnote 16). Each onlending will be undertaken based on terms and 
conditions specified in the loan and project agreements.  
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
22.  The APG will be the executing agency, and will establish a project leading group (PLG) 
to  guide  overall  project  implementation  and  to  ensure  proper  coordination  across  the 
municipalities and agencies concerned. The PLG will be chaired by a vice-governor with heads 
of  provincial  agencies  and  municipalities  and  counties  concerned  as  members.  The  vice-
governor will chair the PLG’s quarterly meetings to review  project implementation, resolve 
coordination issues, and ensure timely project completion. The APG has established and staffed 
the project management office in the CLMA to coordinate and manage project implementation 
on a day-to-day basis.   
 
23.  The 15 subprojects under the four outputs will be implemented in two participating 
municipalities—Hefei18 and Lu’an, and in seven participating counties—Changfeng, Chaohu, 
Feidong, Feixi, Hanshan, Lujiang, and Wuwei.19 A PMO has also been established in each 
municipality  and  county  to  coordinate  implementation  of  the  subprojects  on  behalf  of  the 
respective  governments.  The  15  subprojects  will  be  implemented  by  13  implementing 
                                                
17 Interest includes a maturity premium of 0.2%, which is based on the above loan terms and the government’s 
choice of repayment option and dates. 
18 The CLMA falls under the Hefei municipality. However, it receives a separate allocation under the loan. 
19 Five of these participating counties—Changfeng, Chaohu, Feidong, Feixi, and Lujiang—are under the jurisdiction 
of the Hefei municipality but will receive fund allocations under the loan to finance their respective subprojects.

6 
agencies,20 which will be responsible for day-to-day project implementation. The capacity of the 
PMOs and implementing agencies has been assessed and a capacity strengthening plan is 
included  in  the  consultants’  terms  of  reference.  The  implementation  arrangements  are 
summarized in Table 3 and described in detail in the PAM (footnote 16).

implementing three subprojects while each of the remaining implementing agencies will implement a subproject.

7 
III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
A.  Technical 
24.  Due diligence assessed the technical feasibility and sustainability of the project. The 
technical design of the project and its outputs have been aligned with sector strategies and 
priorities and have incorporated international and national best practices.21 The implementation 
schedule and project management arrangements have been assessed as appropriate. The 
operation of project facilities will be undertaken by the implementing agencies, which, with 
capacity  strengthened,  will  have  adequate  professional  operators.  International  consulting 
services will provide technical support to the PMOs and implementing agencies to ensure that (i) 
ADB and PRC safeguard policies and regulations are fully complied with; and (ii) procurement 
and  contract  management,  financial  management,  fund  withdrawal  and  disbursement,  and 
reporting are in accordance with ADB and PRC requirements. The project design has a number 
of  innovative features,  including  integration  of  the  Chao  Lake  Environmental  Rehabilitation 
Master Plan into the project design, support for CLMA capacity building, and pilot rural nonpoint 
source pollution control. 
 
B.  Economic and Financial 
25.  The economic analysis of the overall project confirms that the project is economically 
viable, with an economic internal rate of return of 13.1%.22 The economic net present value at 
12% discount rate is CNY143.2 million, and the economic benefit–cost ratio is 1:1. Sensitivity 
tests indicate that the overall project is sensitive to both cost increases and benefit decreases, 
with a 7.5% increase in investment costs or a 5.4% decrease in benefits being required to 
reduce  the  economic  internal  rate  of  return  to  less  than  12%.  The  financial  analysis 
demonstrates that the final borrowers of the loan—the municipal governments of Hefei and 
Lu’an, and the county governments of Changfeng, Chaohu, Feidong, Feixi, Hanshan, Lujiang, 
and Wuwei—will be able to generate sufficient revenue to repay the loan.23 Annual debt service 
as  a  portion  of  total  revenue  in  2018  is  estimated  to  range  between  0.20%  (for  Hefei 
municipality) and 0.68% (for Lu’an municipality). The analysis also confirms that the individual 
wastewater treatment subprojects are financially feasible, with financial internal rates of return 
ranging between 2.6% and 4.0%, all well in excess of the estimated weighted average cost of 
capital of 1.4%. Moreover, the financial feasibility of each wastewater treatment subproject 
would hold in most adverse scenarios analyzed. The financial internal rate of return of the solid-
waste management subcomponent is estimated at 10.4%, also well in excess of the weighted 
average cost of capital and robust to most adverse conditions. 
 
C.  Governance 
26.  The financial management assessment of the implementing agencies shows that their 
capacity is adequate to perform accounting and financial reporting to satisfy the needs for 
project  implementation,  but  training  in  ADB  procedures  will  be  required  in  procurement, 
disbursement,  project  management,  and  accounting  systems.  Issues  and  deficiencies 
associated with the entities’ financial management systems have been identified and capacity 
development measures were included to ensure that the implementing agencies are able to 
meet  the  subprojects’  accounting  and  reporting  requirements.  The  procurement  capacity 
assessment  indicates  that  the  executing  agency  and  the  implementing  agencies  have 
                                                
21 Sector Assessment (Summary): Agriculture and Natural Resources (accessible from the list of linked documents in 
Appendix 2). 
22 Economic Analysis (Summary) (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
23 Financial Analysis (Summary) (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

8 
established procurement procedures and staffing and have significant procurement experience 
but lack specific procurement experience with foreign-funded projects, including ADB-financed 
projects.24 The early engagement of a tendering agent will mitigate resultant risks but extensive 
training and support on ADB procurement policies and procedures should be provided. 
 
27.  ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with the APG, the PMOs, and implementing agencies. The specific policy requirements and 
supplementary measures are described in the PAM (footnote 16). 
 
D.  Poverty and Social 
28.  The rural poor population of the Chao Lake region is estimated at 2.2 million, with a rural 
poverty incidence of 17% using the 2011 national poverty line of CNY2,300. The estimated total 
rural poor population of the project area is 0.9 million, with a rural poverty incidence of 14%. The 
project will create approximately 9,000 person-years of direct employment for  about 2,800 
people, generating an estimated CNY400 million in earnings over 5 years. About one-third of 
the work will be skilled positions and about 40% of the unskilled work will be set aside for poor 
people. There will be an estimated 4,180 direct jobs during the project operation phase, and this 
could generate estimated annual earnings of CNY95 million; 75% of the positions are expected 
to be unskilled or semiskilled. The project is classified as ―effective gender mainstreaming.‖ A 
gender action plan to maximize gender design features for the project has been prepared to 
ensure that (i) women benefit from labor opportunities created by the project to empower them 
economically, especially if they are among the households affected by livelihood impacts; (ii) 
women  participate  in  capacity  building  measures  and  that  their  particular  requirements 
regarding training are considered so as to improve their choices and living standard; and (iii) 
women have access to decision-making processes affecting the project, in particular village 
environmental  committees.25 A  summary  poverty  reduction  and  social  strategy  containing 
poverty and social impacts and mitigation measures has been developed.26 A social action plan 
has also been prepared and is included in the PAM (footnote 16). 
 
29.  By improving wastewater collection and treatment for an estimated 1.4 million people, 
the  project  supports  achievement  of  the  Millennium  Development  Goal  for  environmental 
sustainability, which aims to halve the proportion of people without sustainable access to safe 
drinking water and basic sanitation by 2015. The project will improve the living standards of the 
people in the project area by providing safer and more spacious public spaces along the rivers, 
and  by  creating  access  to  wastewater  treatment  in  areas  that  are  unserviced.  The  local 
government price bureau will organize a hearing prior to any increase on the tariff for water, 
wastewater,  or  solid  waste  to  discuss  the  amount  of  the  increase  acceptable  to  poor 
households. Local governments will establish a differential price mechanism for urban and rural 
areas so the poor are given preferential rates for wastewater and solid waste. 
 
E.  Safeguards 
30.  Environmental assessment. The project classification for environment is category A. A 
consolidated environmental impact assessment (EIA) report and an environmental management 
plan (EMP) were prepared following ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009).27 The EIA is 
consistent with the domestic environmental assessment reports approved in February 2012 by 
the  four  municipality  environmental  protection  bureaus  in  the  project  area.  Adequate 
                                                
24 Procurement Capacity Assessment (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
25 Gender Action Plan (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
26 Summary Poverty Reduction and Social Strategy (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
27 Environmental Impact Assessment (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

9 
consultations were conducted with affected persons and stakeholders, and the EIA and EMP 
reports  have  been  disclosed  on  the  ADB  website.  The  EMP  includes  establishment  of  a 
grievance redress mechanism, which has been discussed and agreed upon with the APG. The 
APG, through the provincial PMO, will be responsible for overall implementation and compliance 
with  the  EMP  mitigation  and  monitoring  plans,  institutional  strengthening  and  capacity 
development arrangements and reporting, and initiating corrective actions or measures. The 
PMO will have final responsibility for implementing a grievance redress mechanism for handling 
any  disputes.  The  institutional  capacity  of  the  PMO  to  implement  the  EMP  and  ensure 
compliance with the safeguard policy of ADB is considered adequate with institutional capacity 
strengthening to be provided by loan implementation consultants. A capacity building program, 
which includes environmental monitoring, has been included in the project activities.  
 
31.  The project is expected to generate significant environmental benefits: (i) approximately 
1,660 tons of total nitrogen and 609 tons of total phosphorus will be removed from the Chao 
Lake  basin  through  dredging  and  disposal  of  2.14  million  cubic  meters  of  sediment;  (ii) 
wastewater collection and treatment will reduce pollutant loadings in the river systems each day 
by 12,796 tons of biochemical oxygen demand, 23,821 tons of chemical oxygen demand, 
15,768 tons of suspended solids, 1,331 tons of total nitrogen, 266 tons of total phosphorus, and 
1,713 tons of ammonia nitrogen; and (iii) the rehabilitated wetlands will remove an estimated 47 
tons of total nitrogen, 12 tons of total phosphorus, 168 tons of biochemical oxygen demand, 56 
tons of chemical oxygen demand, and 28 tons of ammonia nitrogen each year. Further, the 
three artificial wetlands constructed under the project will provide resting, nesting, feeding, 
breeding,  and  nursery  habitats  for  wildlife,  promoting  biodiversity  in  Chao  Lake.  Possible 
adverse environmental impacts and risks during construction and operational phases are dust, 
noise, air, and water pollution during construction; suspended solids released from stirred up 
sediments; and odor from WWTPs. All impacts are expected to be prevented or minimized to an 
acceptable level through effective implementation of the EMP and capacity building activities. 
 
32.  Indigenous  peoples  and  involuntary  resettlement.  In  accordance  with  ADB’s 
Safeguard Policy Statement, the project is classified category C for indigenous peoples. The 
population in the project area is ethnically homogenous mainstream Han. There are no impacts 
on ethnic minorities or indigenous peoples’ groups in the project area. The project is classified 
category A for involuntary resettlement. Although the impacts of land acquisition on most of the 
3,200 affected people are minor, even after design optimization more than 50 people will be 
affected by house demolition and around 200 people will suffer significant loss of agricultural 
land which leads to loss of more than 10% of their income-generating assets. Major design 
optimizations were undertaken to improve both the efficiency of the overall project and to reduce 
resettlement and associated social disruptions. After these design optimizations, the project will 
affect 20 villages of 11 townships in nine counties, permanently acquiring 1,251 mu28 of land 
(1,202 mu or 96.1%, as cultivated land) and temporarily occupying 1,789 mu of land. An 
estimated 3,050 square meters of buildings (13 houses and other nonresidential structures) will 
be demolished. A total of 3,168 persons in 817 households will be permanently affected by land 
acquisition and house demolition. The cost estimate for land acquisition and resettlement is 
CNY92.2 million. Compensation will be paid to the affected people and villages. Part of the 
compensation will be used for social insurance for the affected people, based on their choice. 
 
33.  Detailed  compensation,  mitigation,  and  training  measures  are  included  in  the  draft 
resettlement plans.29 The Anhui PMO, local PMOs, and implementing agencies are responsible 
for preparing, reviewing, financing, implementing, monitoring, and reporting on resettlement. 
The  Anhui  PMO  will  engage  an  agency  for  external  monitoring.  Loan  implementation 
                                                
28 A mu is a Chinese unit of measurement (1 mu = 666.67 square meters). 
29 Resettlement Plan (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

10 
consultants will develop the capacity of offices responsible for implementing the resettlement 
plans. A grievance redress mechanism has been established to provide affected people with 
sequential steps to follow in case of grievance. Affected people have been informed of the 
measures in the resettlement plans and grievance steps through public meetings and other 
means to ensure that they are aware of their entitlements and legal rights. 
 
F.  Risks and Mitigating Measures 
34.  Major risks and mitigating measures are summarized in Table 4 and described in detail 
in the risk assessment and risk management plan.30  
 
Table 4: Summary of Risks and Mitigating Measures 
Risks  Management Measures 
The CLMA is a new organization with  Ensure provincial PLG is established with representation from all involved 
limited institutional capacity.  sectors and locations. 
Implement the CLMA capacity building component in a timely manner. 
The CLMA, as PMO, has limited  Ensure PLG includes representatives from Hefei and Lu’an municipalities, 
authority to cooperate with local  and Wuwei and Hanshan counties. Engage the project implementation 
governments of Lu'an, Hanshan, and  consultant. Monitor and report during implementation. 
Wuwei.   
Wastewater and solid waste tariffs  Loan assurance includes agreeing on tariff increases. 
are not increased in a timely manner  Provincial finance bureau will pay debt service on the loan if there is a 
and  by a sufficient amount.  shortfall of funds. 
Finalizing O&M arrangements is  Ensure that implementing agencies establish or appoint an O&M agency at

CLMA = Chao Lake Management Authority, O&M = operation and maintenance, PLG = project leading group, PMO = project 
management office, WWTP = wastewater treatment plant. 
Source: Asian Development Bank. 
 
IV.  ASSURANCES 
35.  The government and the APG have assured ADB that implementation of the project 
shall conform to all applicable ADB policies including those concerning anticorruption measures, 
safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as described in detail 
in the PAM (footnote 16) and loan documents. The government and the APG have agreed with 
ADB on certain covenants for the project, which are set forth in the loan agreement and project 
agreement. 
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
36.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and  recommend  that  the  Board  approve  the  loan  of 
$250,000,000  to  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  for  the  Anhui  Chao  Lake  Environmental 
Rehabilitation Project, from ADB’s ordinary capital resources, with interest to be determined in 
accordance with ADB’s London interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending facility; for a term 
of 25 years, including a grace period of 5 years; and such other terms and conditions as are 
substantially  in  accordance  with  those  set  forth  in  the  draft  loan  and  project  agreements 
presented to the Board. 
 
Haruhiko Kuroda 
President 
24 October 2012
